source.longname: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
source.spanish_name: Oficina del Alto Comisionado de las Naciones Unidas para los Refugiados
source.name: UN High Commissioner for Refugees

fields.title: Ukraine Situation Flash Update #45 (21 April 2023)
fields.body:
**PEOPLE FORCED TO FLEE** 

More details: UNHCR Operational Data Portal Ukraine Refugee Situation . 

8,172,189 Individual refugees from Ukraine recorded across Europe (18 April) 

5,044,039* Refugees from Ukraine registered for temporary protection or similar national protection schemes in Europe (18 April) 

5,352,000 Estimated number of internally displaced people (IDPs) in Ukraine (23 January) Internal Displacement Report 

**RECENT HIGHLIGTHS**   

- UNHCR published the Regional Protection Analysis #2 on 19 April, based on surveys, focus group discussions and border monitoring conducted between October 2022 and January 2023 in Hungary, Poland, the Republic of Moldo- va, Romania, and Slovakia. Findings point out that 22% of refugee households have at least one member with specif- ic needs; these households encounter more difficulties ac- cessing appropriate services, which potentially influences return decisions. Of all respondents, 27% were employed, albeit many were overqualified in low-paying jobs due to language barriers, limited childcare and non-recognition of qualifications. In 25% of refugee households, docu- mentation issues were reported, with 30% being unable to replace documents in their host country. Among the recommendations in the report are the systematic early identification of people at heightened risk to support their access to adequate assistance and documentation, and addressing barriers to decent employment by expanding upskilling and language training, facilitating skills recogni- tion and disseminating information about refugee rights in the labour market.   

- You can find out more about the situation and the response in Ukraine and the region on the dedicated UNHCR Ukraine Emergency website.

text:
# Ukraine Situation Flash Update #45 (21 April 2023)

**PEOPLE FORCED TO FLEE** 

More details: UNHCR Operational Data Portal Ukraine Refugee Situation . 

8,172,189 Individual refugees from Ukraine recorded across Europe (18 April) 

5,044,039* Refugees from Ukraine registered for temporary protection or similar national protection schemes in Europe (18 April) 

5,352,000 Estimated number of internally displaced people (IDPs) in Ukraine (23 January) Internal Displacement Report 

**RECENT HIGHLIGTHS**   

- UNHCR published the Regional Protection Analysis #2 on 19 April, based on surveys, focus group discussions and border monitoring conducted between October 2022 and January 2023 in Hungary, Poland, the Republic of Moldo- va, Romania, and Slovakia. Findings point out that 22% of refugee households have at least one member with specif- ic needs; these households encounter more difficulties ac- cessing appropriate services, which potentially influences return decisions. Of all respondents, 27% were employed, albeit many were overqualified in low-paying jobs due to language barriers, limited childcare and non-recognition of qualifications. In 25% of refugee households, docu- mentation issues were reported, with 30% being unable to replace documents in their host country. Among the recommendations in the report are the systematic early identification of people at heightened risk to support their access to adequate assistance and documentation, and addressing barriers to decent employment by expanding upskilling and language training, facilitating skills recogni- tion and disseminating information about refugee rights in the labour market.   

- You can find out more about the situation and the response in Ukraine and the region on the dedicated UNHCR Ukraine Emergency website.
summary: As of April 18th, 2021, 8,172,189 individual refugees from Ukraine have been recorded across Europe, with 5,044,039 registered for temporary protection or similar national protection schemes. Additionally, an estimated 5,352,000 internally displaced people (IDPs) are in Ukraine. UNHCR recently published a Regional Protection Analysis #2 which found that 22% of refugee households have at least one member with specific needs, and 27% of refugees are employed in low-paying jobs due to language barriers and non-recognition of qualifications. Recommendations include early identification of people at heightened risk, addressing barriers to decent employment, and disseminating information about refugee rights in the labour market. More information can be found on the UNHCR Ukraine Emergency website.
